title: A multi-omics longitudinal study of the murine retinal response to chronic low-dose irradiation and simulated microgravity
background: Spaceflight hazards including microgravity and space radiation can adversely affect biological systems, particularly the central nervous system and ocular function. Understanding these impacts is crucial for crew health and performance during and after missions.
objective: To assess longitudinal epigenomic and transcriptomic retinal responses to simulated spaceflight hazards (hindlimb unloading and gamma irradiation) at 7 days, 1 month, and 4 months post-exposure.
methods: Multi-omics analysis of NASA GeneLab dataset using RNA-seq for transcriptomics and reduced representation bisulfite sequencing (RRBS) for DNA methylation, with differential expression and methylation analysis, gene set enrichment analysis, and over-representation analysis.
results: Identified 4178 differentially methylated loci/regions and 457 differentially expressed genes across conditions. Nucleotide metabolism processes were enriched in all groups with activation at 1 month and suppression at 7 days and 4 months. Wnt and Notch signaling showed alterations at 4 months post-exposure. 23 genes showed significant changes in both methylation and expression.
conclusion: Spaceflight hazard analogs induce persistent molecular changes in the retina with distinct temporal patterns, highlighting Wnt signaling and nucleotide metabolism as key pathways affected by combined radiation and microgravity exposure.

core_problems: Combined effects of microgravity and radiation
benefits: Reveals temporal patterns of spaceflight effects
Provides mechanistic insights into ocular pathology
key_outcomes: Wnt signaling pathway alterations at 4 months
23 genes with coordinated expression and methylation changes
Distinct responses to individual vs. combined hazards
extracted_entities.confidence: Validated through multiple time points and integrated omics approaches, though limited by sample size and analog limitations
gaps: Gamma radiation doesn't fully represent space radiation
Bulk analysis obscures cell-type specific effects
opportunities: Use of more realistic space radiation analogs

learning_notes.note: The study identified 4178 differentially methylated loci/regions and 457 differentially expressed genes in mouse retinas exposed to spaceflight hazard analogs, with the highest methylation changes (957 DML/DMR) occurring in the combined hindlimb unloading + irradiation group at 1 month, demonstrating the substantial epigenetic impact of combined space stressors.

Nucleotide metabolism biological processes showed consistent enrichment across all exposure groups with activation at 1 month but suppression at both 7 days and 4 months post-exposure, revealing a time-dependent regulatory pattern that may reflect adaptive responses to spaceflight stressors.

Wnt signaling pathway alterations were particularly prominent at 4 months post-exposure in the combined hazard group, with both expression and methylation changes affecting genes including Wnt3, Wnt11, Wnt7b, Lrp6, and Tnik, suggesting long-term disruption of this critical developmental and homeostatic pathway.

Twenty-three genes showed coordinated changes in both expression and methylation, including retinal function genes like Crybb3 (crystallin) and inflammatory response genes like Fgfr1, with some showing negative correlation (methylation silencing) and others positive correlation between methylation and expression changes.

The study revealed hazard-specific biological processes, with microtubule dynamics enriched exclusively in hindlimb unloading, DNA conformation changes in irradiation, and postsynaptic density organization in combined exposure, indicating distinct molecular responses to different spaceflight stressors.

Several genes implicated in human ocular diseases showed persistent changes, including Adamts5 (age-related macular degeneration) maintaining hypermethylation at 4 months post-irradiation, and multiple crystallin genes (Cryaa, Cryba1, Crybb3) dysregulated at 7 days, connecting spaceflight exposure to terrestrial eye pathology mechanisms.

The multi-omics approach leveraging NASA's GeneLab database enabled re-analysis of existing space-relevant biological data, demonstrating how open-access omics resources can maximize scientific return from limited spaceflight experiments and ground-based analog studies.
